awd_abstract_narration:
A mathematical proof can be thought of as an argument that uses accepted rules of logic to validate the claims in a mathematical statement. Becoming proficient at producing mathematically valid proofs is one of the central expectation for undergraduate mathematics majors, but has also been identified as one of the key challenges that these students face. Working toward addressing this problem, this project, "Promoting Reasoning In Undergraduate Mathematics (PRIUM)", will implement a cycle of assessing student knowledge, planning and implementing instructional responses to those findings, assessing learning, followed by reflection on assessment outcomes and further course revision. More specifically, the project will employ results from a strong body of research in undergraduate mathematics education (RUME) about student learning and understanding of mathematical proving in order to inform instructional and assessment decisions in upper-division undergraduate mathematics courses that focus on mathematical proofs. Key to this project is the collaboration between mathematics educators who are experts in the research about student learning and research mathematicians who are the instructors of the courses. Also key to this project is the emphasis on connecting education research and classroom practice.

In this project, investigators from Georgia State University (GSU) and North Dakota State University (NDSU) will support research mathematicians in the implementation of education-research-based methods for teaching and assessing learning of proof at two large state universities. Using interviews, surveys, artifacts (e.g., annual department assessment reports), and discussions/presentations at mini-conferences, the proposed project will address the following research questions: (1) How do mathematicians make use of a RUME-based model for assessing proof in their instruction? (2) What impact does this approach have on student understanding of proof made evident by the extent to which students demonstrate a qualitative understanding of the local and global concepts of proofs? (3) How does this collaboration between mathematicians and mathematics educators impact professors' attitudes toward implementing research-based methods of mathematics teaching and assessment? (4) What changes, if any, have the participating mathematics departments instituted as a result of this project over a three-year period?

Project Outcomes

 

PRIUM was designed to develop, implement, and test a creative approach to support mathematicians, working collaboratively with mathematics education researchers, as they adopt and implement education research about the teaching and learning of proof in the undergraduate mathematics programs at NDSU and GSU, two doctoral research institutions.

 

The following project outcomes were relevant to the intellectual merits of the proposed work. Mathematics educators and mathematicians from both institutions collaborated to design and implement assessment items focused on improving student comprehension of proof. These proof assessments were informed by mathematics education research. In particular, we implemented a framework for assessing proof “An assessment model for proof comprehension in undergraduate mathematics “, published by Mejia-Ramos, et al. in 2012.

 

Mathematicians and mathematics educators worked collaboratively on implementing an assessment framework that provided credible evidence of students’ learning of mathematical reasoning and proof as they progress through the undergraduate program. The faculty insights gained by this experience have promoted reflective changes of instructional practices at the two participating institutions. The group has continued to work together after the grant expired. The implementation of the framework also presented some challenges. One of such challenges was to write the assessment items that will assess different levels of students’ understanding of proof. To resolve this challenge, we, as a team, engaged in developing a framework for both writing questions that get at student understanding of proof and also to help develop questions that provoke student understanding.

 

Therefore, an important outcome of the implementation, testing, and revision activities of this project is a resulting (draft) model for using research-developed course and programmatic assessment framework to strengthen and improve student learning that could be implemented widely in other mathematics departments.

 

Key outcomes of the broader impact included faculty and supported graduate students’ active reporting of the results from this work at a variety of venues including publications in peer-reviewed journals and conference proceedings, conference talks, poster presentations, and doctoral dissertations. As of the conclusion of this report, one peer-reviewed article has been published, four peer-reviewed articles in conference proceedings were published, three doctoral dissertations completed, and 6 conference presentations. Additionally, PRIUM faculty are currently writing a joint paper that presents the results of this work and the new PRIUM Framework. We plan to submit this paper in Spring 2023.

 

As a capstone to our work, PRIUM faculty jointly organized a multi-state workshop and mini-conference in which we presented our work and our developing framework. Twenty-seven faculty from 17 different colleges participated at Georgia State University in May 2022 (postponed due to pandemic). PRIUM faculty developed workshop activities to broaden both their own understanding of how faculty interacted with the new framework as well as receiving feedback from the participants to revise the new Framework. The two days of activities allowed for deep conversations and reflections on student learning. This work also broadened our PRIUM team and we have two new research mathematicians who have committed to collaborate with us to implement our new Framework at Brooklyn College, City University of New York.

 

In summary, PRIUM work continues as we take what we have learned from this experience to further develop a PRIUM Framework that may be adopted across campuses.
